chapter.text:
Chapter 1 (Test Data)
Violet Sorrengail is told her path has changed: no quiet scribe life, no safe corridors of archives—she is going to the riders’ quadrant. She tries to argue with logic and precedent; her mother answers with authority and finality. Violet’s body protests before her mind finishes processing: old pain, weak joints, the familiar cost of simply standing too long. Around her, the war college feels like a machine built to grind down hesitation.

She packs quickly—practical items, notes, a few comforts—and runs through survival rules she’s heard whispered: trust slowly, watch the parapets, and never assume someone won’t push you.

By night, she studies maps and rumors. Riders are power and politics. Dragons are not pets. And in Basgiath, the line between training and execution is… not a line at all.

Chapter 2 (Test Data)
Basgiath’s stone towers loom like a verdict. Cadets gather in a tense crowd, pretending not to look afraid. Violet keeps to the edge, conserving energy, measuring exits, noticing who watches whom. Some recruits boast loudly—performance as armor. Others stay silent, their eyes fixed on the narrow walkways that bridge the heights.

A senior cadet reads the rules with a smile that doesn’t reach their eyes: there will be tests, eliminations, and consequences. Violet hears the unspoken part: the college is not obligated to keep you alive.

When the first trial is announced, the crowd shifts. Violet’s pulse spikes. She fights the reflex to freeze and instead breaks the problem into parts: footing, pace, breathing, and angles. Survive the first hour. Then the next.

Chapter 3 (Test Data)
The parapet is narrower than Violet imagined—stone worn smooth by rain and years of terrified footsteps. Wind tugs at clothing and balance alike. Violet forces her gaze forward, not down. She counts steps in sets of ten. Her muscles tremble, then stabilize into a careful rhythm.

Halfway across, someone behind her stumbles. The sound—boot scraping stone—hits her like a physical shove. Violet’s instinct is to help, but helping is a liability here. She compromises: she shifts just enough to avoid collision, keeps moving, keeps breathing.

On the far side, cadets land in messy relief. Some laugh too loudly. Some vomit. Violet rests her hands on her knees, waiting for the shaking to stop.

Then she notices the eyes on her—the ones that evaluate weakness the way merchants evaluate flawed goods.

Chapter 4 (Test Data)
Rumors become strategy at breakfast. Violet learns names without volunteering her own. Alliances form fast—less friendship, more mutual insurance. A cadet with a charming smile offers her a seat, then tests her with pointed questions about her mother’s influence.

Violet answers with careful half-truths, keeping her tone neutral. She knows status makes her a target: some will want to use her, others will want to hurt her to prove a point.

Training begins with pain: sprint drills, combat stances, and instructors who correct mistakes by making them unforgettable. Violet adapts. She uses leverage, timing, and distance. She listens more than she speaks.

At night, she writes down what matters: who pushes too hard, who watches quietly, and who seems to enjoy cruelty.

She also writes one private rule: never confuse surviving with winning—yet.

Chapter 5 (Test Data)
The first real confrontation comes without warning. A stronger cadet corners Violet in a corridor, flanked by two friends. The message is simple: you don’t belong here, and your body proves it.

Violet’s fear sharpens into clarity. She can’t outmuscle them. So she changes the game. She talks—calm, precise—baiting impatience, pulling attention to noise and timing. When the opening appears, she moves fast: a short strike to disrupt balance, a shove into the wall, and a dash into the flow of passing cadets.

She doesn’t win the fight.

But she escapes it.

Later, alone, she looks at her bruised hands and realizes something unsettling: Basgiath is teaching her a language she never wanted to speak.

And somewhere beyond stone and steel, dragons are waiting—indifferent, dangerous, and impossibly alive.

metadata.title: ts2 Fourth Wing (The Empyrean, #1)
metadata.author: Rebecca Yarros
metadata.intro: Violet Sorrengail expects a quiet life as a scribe, but her ruthless general mother forces her into Basgiath War College, where dragon riders are trained and cadets die easily. Small, fragile, and living with chronic illness, Violet must survive brutal trials, deadly classmates and volatile dragons. As she bonds with unexpected allies—including a feared dragon and the enemy of her family—she’s pulled into a rebellion that questions everything she’s been taught.
